This is not legislation, it's an Executive order. It was blocked by a court injunction lat summer, and the Supreme Court deadlocked on the appeal, so the injunction stood. In order for this to be implemented, Obama would have to defy a court order forbidding implementation. If he did that, it would probably open up a new set of lawsuits that would keep the issue unresolved until after Trump's inauguration. Here's the Wikipedia page: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deferred_Action_for_Parents_of_Americans

In theory, constitutional law professor and future Supreme Court Justice Obama will not defy a Supreme Court decision.  In practice, why the hell not?  It is wildly improbable, but not inconceivable, that he will reissue his executive order, or most of it, and instruct his minions to "implement" it, whatever the people who wrote this Q thinks that means.  Unlikely, but fun.  One recalls that Andrew Jackson, no scholar of any kind, pronounced famously, "John Marshall has made his decision, now let him enforce it" even before Mussolini famously inquired "How many divisions has the Pope?" Staying at zero, but entertaining myself with the thought--an extremely cheap form of entertainment, by the way, which I commend to all.

Some new developments: "NEW LAWSUIT HAS A REAL CHANCE TO HELP BRING OBAMA'S IMMIGRATION ACTIONS BACK IN MANY STATES" 
http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2016/08/25/lawsuit_on_obama_immigration_executive_actions_could_restore_deferred_deportation.html Slate is reporting that an ambitious lawsuit is attempting to unfreeze Obama's executive action on immigration in 24 states.   A summary from the article: When POTUS tried to implement his executive action on immigration, deferring deportation for undocumented parents of citizens and permanent residents, 26 states sued. The argument was that POTUS was exceeding his executive authority.  The state of Texas also argued that the the executive action would bring unduly burden on the state as it would then have to issue driver's licenses to undocumented people, resulting in expenses for the state. POTUS lawyers had argue the state could simply raise the prices of driver's licences to make up for it.   "U.S. District Judge Andrew Hanen agreed, issuing a preliminary injunction to halt the program’s implementation in all 50 states. Soon after, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit affirmed Hanen’s decision. Then, last June, the SCOTUS deadlocked on the merits of the program, leaving the judge’s ruling in place without actually affirming it. Now, the question is "can one judge actually block the implementation of a new federal program across the country, even in states that would welcome the program?"  The new lawsuit argues that it cannot. The lawsuit's plaintiff, New York resident Martín Jonathan Batalla Vidal, had received deferred deportation status through the program, but saw that status revoked after Hanen’s decision. "The problem here, Batalla Vidal claims, is one of standing—the rules governing who can bring a federal case, and to whom a federal court decision applies. Batalla Vidal argues that Hanen’s injunction was “unlawfully broad” because the 26 plaintiff states “lacked standing to seek or obtain a nationwide injunction.”  These states may have had standing to halt the program’s implementation within their borders—but they don’t have standing to block the program elsewhere. Texas, which initiated this litigation, argued that undocumented immigrants harm the state by forcing it to help pay for their driver’s licenses. But how is Texas harmed when New York resident Batalla Vidal receives deferred deportation status? Batalla Vidal argues that it isn’t. And if Texas didn’t have standing to block the program in states outside that litigation, then Hanen lacked jurisdiction to halt the program in states that didn’t sue to stop it." Apparently, and according to the article, the lawsuit touches on "basic principles of federalism: One state doesn’t get to control what other states do.  "Why should Texas get to prevent Batalla Vidal from staying in the country when New York wants to let him remain? The suit also takes advantage of the Supreme Court’s continued deadlock. June’s 4-4 split set no precedent, allowing a different court to arrive at the opposite conclusion of Hanen and the 5th Circuit. If Batalla Vidal can persuade a federal judge in New York to affirm the legality of Obama’s actions, he could probably get his deferred deportation status back. That success would spur lawsuits in every other circuit but the 5th, creating a roadmap for the restoration of the program in nearly half the country. " This is definitely a case we want to keep an eye on. Although, it is not clear if some states unblocking POTUS' executive order would result in this question resolving as a "yes."   I will increase prob by 15 just in case.

Here's a spanner for the works:  First week in January, Clinton has won the election, Garland or someone more liberal is or will be on the Supreme Court. This Q goes from 0 to 100 faster than your Lamborghini.   Luckily this can't be done secretly in the US, so we'll all have time to adjust our numbers.  Just one of the many left-field possibilities keeping me up nights.

FOR the third time since the death of Antonin Scalia February, a stymied Supreme Court has split 4-4 and failed to come to a decision. Of the three ties, today's deadlock over United States v Texas, a challenge to Barack Obama’s immigration orders, carries the highest stakes. Up to 5m undocumented immigrants who were the intended beneficiaries of Mr Obama’s 2014 executive actions have lost their chance to apply for a programme that would have given them temporary permission to work and relief from deportation. The programme, Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA), sought to protect “hard-working people who have become integrated members of American society” and to keep families from being wrenched apart. DAPA did not confer legal status and was not a path to citizenship, but it gave people whose children were American citizens or permanent residents a chance to “come out of the shadows”, pay taxes and live without the constant fear of immigration agents knocking on their doors. Before DAPA could get off the ground, a lawsuit from Texas and 25 other states claiming the programme was illegal presidential overreach led a federal judge in Brownsville, Texas to put Mr Obama’s plans on hold. The injunction, issued in February 2015 by Judge Andrew Hanen, a known hard-liner on illegal immigration, was upheld in a 2-1 decision later that year by the 5th circuit court of appeals. The Supreme Court agreed in January 2016 to review the appeals court’s ruling and heard arguments in April. The tenor of the hearing suggested that the justices were split in two equal camps over whether Mr Obama’s orders were legal. That suspicion was confirmed on June 23rd, when Chief Justice John Roberts announced the court’s one-line ruling: “The judgment is affirmed by an equally divided Court.”

As it's already been established, SCOTUS is divided on this issue. Last year, a federal judge blocked implementation of Pres. Obama's Executive Action on Immigration, which included the DAPA program, on what were called "narrow technical grounds."  A  federal appeals court subsequently blocked it on broader grounds by a 2-1 vote.  The question in front of the SCOTUS now is "whether the president has the power to temporarily shield the undocumented parents of American citizen children, and give them temporary work permits so that they can support their families for the time being." This is a hugely political issue in an election year, and most especially on a year in which one of two presidential frontrunners has made immigration control, and the deportation of 11 million undocumented people, his main platform.   Attorney's for Pres. Obama  argue that "the president's executive action does not grant citizenship or permanent legal status; it is just a three-year temporary grant of legal status that allows those eligible to work and support themselves and their American citizen children."   In the past, SCOTUS has given the executive branch of government "broad discretion" over immigration policy, "including how the law is to be enforced as well as who should be arrested and deported."

Another argument being made on behalf of Pres. Obama is that "Texas has no legal right to be in court at all because it has not suffered the concrete injury that is required to bring a lawsuit." The State of Texas argues that it would certainly sustain "concrete injury under the president's executive action because the state has a policy of subsidizing driver's licenses, and a large number of people previously considered in the country illegally would be eligible for those licenses if they were granted temporary lawful status by the president's order."   The counter argument of the administration says that this is "a self-inflicted problem for the state, and that Texas is free to charge more for these new driver's licenses if it wishes to." SCOTUS is divided along partisan and ideological lines:  http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/18/politics/supreme-court-immigration-executive-actions-texas/  Chief Justice Roberts and Justice  Alito "seemed particularly concerned with language in the administration's guidance that said the program's recipients would be "lawfully present," which they suggested would contradict immigration law." 
 Alito: "How is it possible to lawfully work in the United States without lawfully being in the United States?" 
Roberts: "I mean, they're lawfully present, and yet, they're present in violation of the law?"
Justice Roberts "also seemed concerned with the scope of the government's argument defending Obama's moves": "Under your argument, could the President grant deferred removal to every unlawful -- unlawfully present alien in the United States right now?" 
 Justice Kennedy suggested that "the president might have strayed into Congress' territory: "It's as if -- that the President is setting the policy and Congress is executing it." "That's just upside down." Justice Ginsburg noted that "there are 11.3 million undocumented aliens in the country and Congress has provided funds for removing about 4 million. "So inevitably, priorities have to be set."
Justice Sotomayor said "there are not enough resources to deport everyone. "They are here whether we want them or not."  Also noted on the CNN article linked above, the GOP Congress was involved at oral arguments as well. "The House of Representatives, in an unusual move, intervened in the case against the administration, and had 15 minutes before the eight justices." Because of Justice Scalia's death in February, only 8 justices are hearing the case.   A split decision between the four Democratic-appointed justices and four GOP-appointed justices would mean the President's executive action on immigration including the DAPA program, will remain blocked and the case will be sent back to the Texas district court.  The issue of Pres. Obama's fight for his legacy is an important one. I think the administration will do all that it possibly can to get a decision in favor of the President's executive order and subsequent implementation. A lot of resources and energy are being devoted by the Obama administration.  And just as much energy is being devoted on the opposite side specially in an increasingly anti-immigration climate in the US.  I could even see a correlation between Trump's entering into the main stream and getting the GOP to fully support him and SCOTUS deciding against the president's executive action or reaching a split decision. But it is a tough fight. I will give the President a slight advantage on this for the time being.

I think the court will push off until a new judge is nominated. Every president for the last half century has granted some form of temporary deportation relief, most often to groups of asylum seekers.v They claim the Obama administration’s programs would force state governments to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on health care, education, law enforcement, and other public benefits associated with the immigrants receiving relief. For instance, Texas could assume up to $500 million in administrative costs for issuing new driver’s licenses, they claim. First, the White House claims that Texas and the other states do not meet the legal threshold to sue the federal government because, among other things, the states could avoid the alleged financial costs by simply choosing not to provide the relevant benefits (e.g., driver’s licenses) court is sympathetic Justice Sonia Sotomayor said there are not enough resources to deport everyone. "They are here whether we want them or not," she said. If a state can sue every time the federal government does something to increase the state's costs, states could sue to challenge almost anything the federal government does," he said.
See United States House of Representatives v. Burwell. On Scotus blog.
Election year hot button issue decision with a skinny court?  Ha!

There are a near definite four votes in favor of the President/the E.O. and Justice Kennedy seemed skeptical that Texas had standing during the oral arguments.  If Kennedy rules that Texas does not have standing to bring this case would be the fifth vote and thereby allow implementation.
A 4-4 decision rescinds the directive and there is no way to implement this plan.  Which is good, this is a congressional issue and congress should resolve this issue with the President.
If Clinton wins maybe if the GOP Senate votes on Garland.

Full US Supreme Court text: http://www.supremecourt.gov/oral_arguments/argument_transcripts/15-674_h3dj.pdf I'm not a lawyer, but a couple points jumped out at me: (US = petitioner; Texas =respondent)
Both Petitioner and Respondent agreed that the Federal government has primary authority to define and implement a deportation plan. Given the fact that Congress has allocated funds that allow for deportation of only about 400,000 per year (goal of 4 million), DAPA defines certain illegal immigrants as essentially low priority for deportation. Respondent attempted to make the case that the ancillary benefits for being "lawfully" in the country creates a legal status of having access to these benefits that include Social Security, medicaire, etc. There was substantial technical discussion of the word lawful. In non-DAPA regulations, applicable over 30 years, certain administrative regulations use the word lawful, but is not a transferable lawfulness within the meaning of immigration policy. In effect, a person could be here unlawfully for immigration, but given deferred action from DAPA or other Executive Actions in the past, and certain statutory programs such as social security, medicaire, or right to work would independently bestow lawfullness for receipt of their programs' benefits.  The justices, in general, seemed reticent of opening up a new line of court cases simply because a state may have indirect or direct costs due to a Executive order or Congressional action that they politically disagree with. It seemed that the justices were examining scope. Could the designation of low priority deportation be isolated as the main element of DAPA? This would allow a possible suit to challenge the regulation of statutory programs and subsequent benefit application to such a wide class of illegal immigrants, but would also allow a finding in general favor of DAPA. Justices, themselves, could sever the DAPA immigration designation from the benefits issue. p.66 of transcript Official ¬ Subject to Final Review
MR. KELLER:..... that doesn't mean that the States don't have a significant interest in who's within their borders. We  have an easily identifiable sovereign interest on who's  within our borders. However ¬¬   JUSTICE GINSBURG: But the State can't  remove anyone, and we still go back to the basic problem: 11.3 million people. Congress is not  appropriating money to ¬¬ to remove more than ¬¬ what is  it? ¬¬ four million of them.  So there are these people that are ¬¬ who are here to stay no matter what. And you have conceded  that the Federal government can say, low priority,  here's your card. Not going to deport you unless we  change our mind.  So the only thing that's involved is the  work, and you haven't challenged that separately.  You're challenging DAPA.   MR. KELLER: And ¬¬ and DAPA itself purports  to grant not only work authorization, but also transform  lawful conduct into lawful conduct.   JUSTICE GINSBURG: We've already gone  through that. We've ¬¬ we have agreed that that means tolerated presence. The government has said, take out that word. It was unfortunate that we used it. What we mean is tolerated presence.   p.67   MR. KELLER: But it's not just an unfortunate slip. When they're granting deferred¬ action status, under their regulations, that is lawful presence. So they want you to take out "lawful presence" from the DAPA memo and pretend "lawful presence" isn't in there. But then when you go into the regulations ¬¬  JUSTICE KAGAN: But then why aren't you challenging the regulations? I mean, I understand what you're saying that DAPA in some sense triggers the regulations, but only because the regulations say what they say, that your real challenge is not to DAPA, which is the nonenforcement part of this. Your real challenge is to the regulations, the fact that non-enforcement  leads to a certain set of results and yet you're not here challenging those regulations.  MR. KELLER: Well, insofar as you'd conceive of our case of challenging those regulations, it would be challenging them as applied to DAPA, but when Congress ¬¬-- JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR: The problem is that you haven't exhausted administratively, and we always require you to do that. There isn't an exception, as I understand it, under the APA, for your failure to exhaust your avenues in the agency first.
Lower forecast after SC session end: question can not close with a negative out come until 1/20/17.

I think the Supreme Court has been and will be very reluctant to set any wide-spreading and non-obvious precedents while there are only 8 justices.  A split decision will not set a precedent, but will uphold the lower courts decision.  Based on the questioning of the "two swing judges", it appears like a 4-4 split is most likely, making implementation prior to inauguration day difficult.

There are several ways in which DAPA would NOT be implemented before January 20:
1) Supreme Court fails to overturn Circuit Court opinion on case. For this to happen, at least four justices have to decide that the states have standing AND win on the merits. On merits, Kennedy seemed favorable to the states. In oral arguments, Alito & Roberts were clearly favorable to states on standing, Thomas silent, and Kennedy was silent. I think this boils down to whether Kennedy agrees with states on standing. Right now, I'm pegging this at about 60% Kennedy agrees with states, so 60% for a 4-4 vote (i.e., no implementation). 
2) The Supreme court rules for the administration, but implementation is blocked through some other means: another court challenge, a delay in implementation past September 30 PLUS Congressional budgeting for FY17 that prohibits spending on DAPA, or some other method. I'm going to peg this conditionally at 10%.  Reversing this, the probabilities then become (% Court rules for admin)*(100%-conditional other blocking) = .4 * .9 = 36%

Supremes likely to be 4-4 on this issue, meaning lower court's injunction stands.    There is a slight chance that DAPA could be passed as legislation by the newly elected Congress in early January 2017, but the Dems would have to have won the House (so they would control the legislative agenda) as well as a large enough majority in the Senate (and enough of a humiliation of Trump at the polls) where there wouldn't be 40 Repubs to filibuster.   Unlikely.

Migrants need America, America needs immigrants as production resources. May be Democrats will support the Democrat. A small step would be interesting, especially when already raised the leg. Perhaps something will be provided which will help to reduce the flow of migrants (after the adoption of the program). Strengthening of Trump during election will be positive for process of implementation.

What a confusing question. I'm reducing it in my head to something like "will SCOTUS generally say 'no' to presidential power in this area?" Seems like a lot of top forecasters are making positive predictions -- more positive than their words will imply. I feel more optimistic than the crowd that SCOTUS will "take Obama's side", whatever that means, but I'm sticking close to consensus because I am confused.

This question reflects the sloppy thinking of the people who write this stuff:  Does "implemented" mean  a go-ahead from the Court, as implied by the subtitle, or some partial or complete administrative action to make something happen?  How is the subtitle helpful, especially if it's meant to be part of the scoring criterion and there isn't a "4-4 Supreme Court," as another question obviously contemplates?  What if part of the programme is given the Court's okey-dokey and some other parts aren't?   Left once again to guess what the writers are getting at, rather than to make a specific prediction on a falsifiable proposition, I'm going with Whatever They Think They Mean, It Probably Won't Happen.
initial forecast, thanks to @Dima-K, @GJDrew et al for discussions

Initial forecast thanks to @lsgold7 @Dima-K and @GJDrew for great summary of legal options.  One issue I haven't seen is whether it makes sense for President Obama to take action (since I'm guessing that he might slow-roll the whole thing even if the SCOTUS should happen to overturn the Texas case which probably won't happen). Highlighting the continuing problems should help motivate migrant communities (more than just Latino) to vote D and no reason to whip up even more anti-illegal feeling right before the election. Also case 1, HRC wins and she'll try to craft some immigration fix that might have to include DAPA but would be better without it. Case 2, If DT wins would President Obama jerk around both individuals who might qualify and the USG troops that would have to deal with it? I'm guessing no, especially since it is reasonable that DT would revoke DAPA (if not DACA). DT also wants to "fix" the whole mess.
Per @GJDrew and @lsgold7's comments in this thread: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/228911

Going to NO now, based on @lsgold7's comments: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/228911 I didn't consider the option of just sitting on the case until next term.  That preserves the TX injunction, doesn't require Roberts to oppose his own judicial philosophy, doesn't make him a villain to conservatives and doesn't leave a 4-4 decision hanging out there.  Sounds like the easiest out.

I am having hardest time forecasting this one because I don't understand underlying the process.  Calling all lawyers!!! Please, if you have some time, could you tell if: 1. USSC is supposed to rule on legality of Texas court's temporary injunction or on legality of Obama's executive order? 
2. USSC *has* to decide one way or another. I.e., can it just send the case back to the lower court with new instructions/interpretations of the law instead? If yes, has such a thing ever happened in USSC?
3. the ruling turns to be 4:4, does the original injunction simply stand? If yes, will it ever expire (as would be expected of something "temporary")?  
4. when June results in DAPA still being temporarily blocked by some mechanism, Obama can simply issue another order before his first one is completely sorted out in courts? 
5. there is some strict legal sense that "implementation" is being referred to?  Thanks!!!  50/50 for now is very appropriate :-)

Background: http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/18/politics/supreme-court-immigration-executive-actions-texas/ First reactions: 1. If the court is split, what is the status quo?  Looks like from that article, it means the Texas judgment stays in place and the program is blocked for now.  Makes me inclined to say NO. 2. But are there any other grounds to vacate, like standing?  It does seem to me that the state of Texas only has very tenuous connection to challenge the action in a lawsuit.  But if the court rules on those grounds, they'll have to vacate the Texas judgment.  Politically, that'll make John Roberts a conservative villain again.   I think John Roberts would love to kick the case on standing.  There's no reason Supreme Court would want to be wading into these politically sensitive issues, if they can avoid it.   Roberts is in general in favor of executive power.  I also think he feels the congress is out of control right now, and he has some responsibility to play the adult in the room.  So he might not like a 4-4 tie, no action result.  I think Roberts goes with his judicial / legal philosophy over expedience.    3. Last issue is whether there's some small print that irks the conservative justices.  There's a big difference between "deferring" action and calling them "lawful" in some way, if you want to guard a symbolic line.  Have to research more about it.
